name: Valerian Root
summary: Valerian root (Valeriana officinalis) is a traditional herbal remedy commonly used for insomnia, anxiety, and stress-related sleep disturbances.
description: Valerian root is derived from the plant *Valeriana officinalis* and has been used for centuries as a natural sedative and anxiolytic. It is thought to enhance gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) signaling in the brain, promoting relaxation and sleep. Research on its efficacy is mixed, but some studies support its use for reducing sleep latency and improving subjective sleep quality. It is generally considered safe for short-term use, though long-term safety is less established.

monitoring_required: Liver function with long-term/high-dose use (rare reports)

items: Helps reduce sleep latency in insomnia
Used for mild anxiety and stress relief

sections.text: Valerian root extracts are believed to increase GABA availability in the brain by inhibiting GABA breakdown and interacting with GABA-A receptors. This promotes sedative, anxiolytic, and sleep-enhancing effects.

adult.typical: 300–600 mg standardized root extract taken 30 minutes to 2 hours before bedtime.
adult.note: May take several days to weeks of nightly use for full effect.

sections.pediatric: Not recommended unless under medical supervision.

sections.text: Effects may be noticed within a week, with maximum benefit after 2–4 weeks of consistent use. Duration of sedation is typically 4–6 hours.

serious: Liver toxicity (rare, mostly with extracts of questionable quality)

other: Avoid combining with alcohol or sedative medications due to additive CNS depression.
Not recommended during pregnancy or lactation.
Long-term continuous use is not well studied.

items: Monitor for next-day drowsiness or impaired concentration

sections.pediatrics: Not routinely recommended; limited safety data
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; monitor for fall risk due to sedation

sections.text: No taper required; generally safe to discontinue abruptly. Some individuals prefer gradual reduction after long-term use.

items: Effects may be modest compared to prescription hypnotics.
Best studied for short-term use in insomnia.
Quality of commercial preparations varies; standardized extracts are preferable.
